channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden Warns Russia That the West Will Not Recognize Putin’s Actions
item.description: The president also said that Mr. Putin should not dare to take his fight into NATO territory, underscoring the unity among the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said during a news conference at the White House on Friday that the world would not recognize Russia’s annexation efforts.

item.title: Ukraine Submits Application to Join NATO
item.description: Ukraine’s desire to join the alliance has long been a source of conflict with Russia, which sees the eastward expansion of NATO as a existential threat.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Office of President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv, Ukraine, leading a meeting on national security on Friday.

item.title: Hurricane Ian Leaves Behind a Staggering Scale of Damage in Florida
item.description: The extent of the damage was difficult to comprehend, even for residents who had survived and rebuilt after other powerful storms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Frances Robles and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Jayme Gershen and Orlando Castro for The New York Times

item.title: Liz Truss’ Woes Multiply After Media Blitz
item.description: In a round of interviews, the prime minister showed little sympathy for the pain that high interest rates could inflict on mortgage holders, critics said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss’s Conservative Party now trails the opposition Labour Party by 33 percentage points in polling.

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Sets Another Record, Hitting 10 Percent in September
item.description: Jumps in energy and food prices again pushed inflation in the 19 countries that use the euro to the highest annual rate recorded since the currency was created.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy

item.title: August PCE Inflation Data Shows Prices Are Stubbornly High
item.description: Inflation stayed far above the Federal Reserve’s goal in August, as prices climbed more quickly than economists expected.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shopping center in Los Angeles this month. Consumers continued to spend in August, the Commerce Department reported.

item.title: Stock Market Ends an Ugly Quarter With Another Volatile Day
item.description: The S&P 500 has fallen for three consecutive quarters, the kinds of losses investors have not faced since 2009.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Even as Iranians Rise Up, Protests Worldwide Are Failing at Record Rates
item.description: Mass protests, once a grave threat to even the fiercest autocrat, have plummeted in effectiveness, a study shows. Factors appear to include polarization, social media and rising nationalist attitudes.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Iranian demonstrators in the streets of the capital, Tehran, last week. Protests erupted around the country after the death of a young woman, Mahsa Amini, following her detainment in police custody.

item.title: Iran Protests Continue Despite Heavy Crackdowns
item.description: Dozens of people have been killed in nationwide demonstrations that erupted almost two weeks ago after Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old woman, died in police custody.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A photo obtained from social media showing protesters in Sanandaj, the capital of Kurdistan Province, Iran, on Wednesday.

item.title: Early Cormac McCarthy Interviews Rediscovered
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author has done vanishingly few interviews during the course of his career. In these early ones, some newly uncovered, he is less guarded.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: Cormac McCarthy at his writing desk in Blount County, Tenn., as printed in the Maryville-Alcoa Times on Feb. 26, 1971.

item.title: Congress Clears Stopgap Spending Bill With $12.3 Billion in Ukraine Aid
item.description: The House passed the bill in its final legislative act before the midterm congressional elections, sending it to President Biden before a midnight deadline when federal funding is set to lapse.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Representative Rosa DeLauro, with President Biden at the White House Congressional Picnic in July, on Friday called the investments in the spending bill “urgent and necessary.”

item.title: House Postpones Stock-Trading Vote
item.description: The majority leader’s announcement that the House would not vote this week on a bill to curb trading by members of Congress punted the issue until after the midterm elections and reflected a rough road ahead.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai and Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland and the majority leader, said the legislation was on hold, at least until after the midterm elections.

item.title: N.F.L.’s Concussion Protocol Under Scrutiny After Tagovailoa Injuries
item.description: The N.F.L. said its concussion protocols were followed when Tua Tagovailoa hit his head on Sunday. On Thursday, the quarterback left the field on a stretcher after a second head hit.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:description: Tagovailoa’s injury Thursday, in a game against the Cincinnati Bengals, was the second time in a week that he appeared to sustain a head injury.

item.title: Can Smartphones Help Predict Suicide?
item.description: A unique research project is tracking hundreds of people at risk for suicide, using data from smartphones and wearable biosensors to identify periods of high danger — and intervene.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katelin Cruz uses a phone and FitBit to submit data about her mood and other metrics to Harvard researchers studying suicidal tendencies. “I think it’s almost easier to tell the truth to a computer,” she said.

item.title: A Year Under the Taliban
item.description: A single year of extremist rule has turned life upside down for Afghans, especially women. A photographer who has long called the country home captured the jarring changes.
item.dc:creator: Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Bros’ Review: Boy Meets Boy Meets Multiplex
item.description: Billy Eichner plays a moody podcaster who has sworn off relationships, but just might find himself in one anyway, in this gay romantic comedy.
item.dc:creator: Amy Nicholson

item.title: The Crisis of Men and Boys
item.description: Men have opportunities, but they’re not taking them.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.category: Of Boys and Men: Why the Modern Male Is Struggling, Why It Matters, and What to Do about It (Book)

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Where’s Biden?
item.description: Why is the president sitting this out?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Shesol

item.title: If Bolsonaro Loses Brazil’s Election, Will He Respect the Result?
item.description: Brazilians are holding our breath.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Barbara
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A man in a shirt with the image of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who is seeking to regain Brazil’s presidency, in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday

item.title: Why China’s Crimes in Xinjiang Cannot Go Unpunished
item.description: China is dragging the world back to a human rights dark age. It’s time to push back.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bequelin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Is the Fed Braking Too Hard?
item.description: It may be raising interest rates too far, too fast.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: Ethereum’s Founder on What Crypto Can — and Can’t — Do
item.description: Vitalik Buterin explains digital currency’s potential to transform our world.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Donald Can’t Quit Maggie
item.description: A Times reporter’s new biography of Trump shows the boundlessness of his self-regard.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.category: Confidence Man: The Making of Donald Trump and the Breaking of America (Book)

item.title: Gerrymandering, the Full Story
item.description: A Times analysis finds that the House of Representative has its fairest map in 40 years, despite recent gerrymandering.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Congressional gerrymandering is a smaller problem than it has been for much of the recent past.

item.title: Florida After Hurricane Ian
item.description: Times reporters on the ground take stock of one of the deadliest storms ever to hit the state.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Sydney Harper, Eric Krupke, Jessica Cheung, Rachel Quester, Luke Vander Ploeg, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Myers Beach, Fla., yesterday. About 700 Floridians have been rescued from floodwater, and 2.4 million residents were without power.

item.title: Modern Love Gay Dad
item.description: A man comes out to his wife — and breaks apart their family. Fifteen years later, we check back in.

item.title: Dreaming of Spaghetti and (Meatless) Meatballs
item.description: Ricotta polpette, vegetarian Swedish meatballs and plant-based meatballs.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: Supreme Court Welcomes Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson in Stately Ceremony
item.description: The investiture of Justice Jackson, the first Black woman to serve on the court, was attended by President Biden and other dignitaries.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. outside the Supreme Court on Friday after her investiture ceremony.

item.title: Trevor Noah Will Leave ‘The Daily Show’
item.description: During a taping of the Comedy Central program Thursday night, he noted that it has been seven years since he replaced Jon Stewart. He will depart at a time to be determined, he said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
item.media:description: Trevor Noah was a 31-year-old South African comic not yet well known in the United States when he became the host of one of the crown jewels of the Comedy Central lineup.

item.title: New York’s Invisible Migrant Crisis
item.description: Thousands of asylum seekers have suddenly arrived in the city with infinite need. What is being done to help them?
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: After arriving by bus in New York from Texas, a family of Venezuelan migrants received clothing and food at a Win shelter in Queens.

item.title: Lula vs. Bolsonaro: What to Know About Brazil’s Election
item.description: Jair Bolsonaro has questioned the integrity of Sunday’s election and trails in polls to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a leftist and former president, who was imprisoned amid a corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times; Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro, left, faces a challenge from Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a former leftist president.

item.title: The Worst Foods and Drinks for Your Teeth
item.description: When assessing how likely a given meal, snack or drink is to harm your dental health, there are two main things to consider, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times

item.title: Is Seltzer Water Just as Healthy as Flat Water?
item.description: Unsweetened carbonated water is a better choice than soda or fruit juice. But don’t overdo it, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: If Food Is Love, My Kids Must Hate Me
item.description: Growing up, I equated great meals with a healthy family dynamic. My children couldn’t care less.
item.dc:creator: Chaunie Brusie

item.title: Can You Get Over a Food Intolerance?
item.description: Foods most often associated with intolerances were chocolate, food additives, citrus fruits, fish, shellfish, milk, cheese, eggs and nuts.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.

item.title: The Secret Lives of Sperm Whales
item.description: Deep in waters rarely seen by humans, these “gentle goliaths” are back from near-extinction.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen
item.category: Sperm Whales: The Gentle Goliaths of the Ocean (Book)

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
